Quotes: "I love that engineers were like superheroes. They would see things that were wrong in the world and then figure out a solution for them."
Bio Info: Monique Warren is an environmental engineer at Lawrence Livermore National Lab. She analyzes and designs environmental treatment technologies for soil and groundwater remediation. Her work is important for restoring soil and water ecosystems and maintaining biodiversity.

Quotes: "Designing renders visible our hopes and dreams. It is the first signal of human intentions."
Bio Info: William McDonough is an architect and globally recognized leader in sustainable development and design. He is a pioneer of the concepts of Cradle to Cradle Design™, the Circular Economy, and the Circular Carbon Economy, notably co-authoring Cradle to Cradle: Remaking The Way We Make Things.

Quotes: "Keep in mind that we're the first generation that actually sees climate change in human history. Most climate change has been us going in and out of ice ages over thousands of years. Now we're seeing things happen over tens of years."
Bio Info: Warren Washington is an internationally recognized expert on atmospheric science and climate research. He was the second African-American to earn a doctorate in the atmospheric sciences in the U.S. He developed groundbreaking atmospheric computer models when he came to the National Center for Atmospheric Research in the early 1960s.

Quotes: "Now that I know a scientist doesn't have to look like Bill Nye or one of those Google Images, I wish I had been able to identify as one earlier."
Bio Info: Rachael Bonoan is a first generation Spanish-speaking researcher in the Crone Lab (Tufts University), and the Schultz Lab (Washington State University, Vancouver) and studies ant-caterpillar interactions in the South Puget Sounds, WA. Dr. Bonoan is passionate about ecology, social insects, and insect pollinators.

Quotes: "But the key is, you can have this great invention, you can have this great design, but how do you get it to the people who most need it?"
Bio Info: Krista Donaldson is the CEO of D-Rev, a non-profit product development company improving the health and incomes of people around the world. She puts her mechanical engineering degree to use by creating affordable medical devices for under-resourced people and people living in developing countries.

Quotes: "I find the stories that are hiding in plain sight; discover the commonalities that weave subjects and disparate narratives together; and tell stories that inspire audiences to feel and dream."
Bio Info: Brynmore Williams is an award-winning documentary film director who specializes in short form documentary profiles, health, and human interest stories. He is a versatile director, cinematographer, and editor whose journalism, commercial, and academia backgrounds can be clearly seen in the work that he produces.

Quotes: "The unknown was always so attractive to me… and still is."
Bio Info: Known most famously as a world-renowned actress, European-American Hedy Lamarr was part of a team that invented and engineered spread spectrum technology, a predecessor to our prevalent wireless communications of today. As an Austrian-born U.S. immigrant, the purpose of her inventions was to help fight the Nazi powers of World War II. Her work helped jumpstart the technology that is now used for cell phones.

Quotes: "If you fight hard, know who you are, and are proud of who you are, you've got a good chance of winning."
Bio Info: Walter Lincoln Hawkins was a chemist and engineer who pioneered advances in polymer coatings that are still used today in modern telecommunications. He was the first African-American on staff at AT&T’s Bell Labs in Murray Hill, NJ, where his work led to many breakthroughs in science and engineering.

Quotes: "The trees were my friends, the fishes were my friends, and when you see change happening and their environment suffering, that creates a deep drive to save them."
Bio Info: Kawika Winter is a native Hawaiian botanist and conservationist. He intertwines scientific knowledge and tools to understand traditional Hawaiian culture and the environment.

Quotes: "Since new developments are the products of a creative mind, we must therefore stimulate and encourage that type of mind in every way possible."
Bio Info: In the late 1800s and early 1900s, famous African-American botanist, agriculturalist, and inventor George Washington Carver promoted crop rotation on cotton farms to ensure that soils were able to get nutrients from nitrogen-fixing plants such as sweet potatoes and peanuts. Dr. Carver knew this system of crop rotation would help poor southern farmers restore health to their soils. He later dedicated his life to promoting racial equality throughout the country.

Quotes: "What I love is that we're doing something that's beneficial not only to my family and yours, but to my grandkids and yours, too."
Bio Info: Dean Williams is a computer scientist who has developed software that facilitates the organizing of weather and climate data so that climate scientists can more easily search and analyze data. His contributions have helped improve our understanding of climate change.

Quotes: "Underlying all of these problems of introducing contamination into our world is the question of moral responsibility — responsibility not only to our own generation but to those of the future."
Bio Info: Rachel Carson was an ecologist who studied ecosystems and their interactions. She is the author of the book Silent Spring that described how pesticides affect populations in ecosystems. Her work helped launch a national environmental movement in the 1960s.

Quotes: "It's worth trying to protect the things we have now."
Bio Info: Born in Taiwan and living in Los Angeles, Asian-American Tony Chang was inspired to become an ecologist. He wanted to escape the crowds of the city, and he now spends as much of his work time as possible out in the natural world.

Quotes: "The history of our planet is written in all these rocks, and we need to learn the lessons from the past to understand the present and future of our planet."
Bio Info: Diego Pol is a paleontologist who is known for his discovery of new species of dinosaurs in Patagonia, Argentina. He has worked on many international projects and published papers. Pol is currently the head of the science department at the Egidio Feruglio paleontology museum in Patagonia.

Quotes: "Information access empowers us to flourish. It gives us equal opportunities to display our talents and choose what we want to do with our lives, based on interest and not based on potential barriers."
Bio Info: Wanda D-M, a Hispanic American, is visually impaired. She is a scientist who pioneered sonification, turning space and satellite data into sound. She grew up in Gurabo, Puerto Rico, became a summer intern at NASA after immigrating to the U.S. for university, and received Google's first annual European Scholarship for Students with Disabilities before obtaining her PhD.

Quotes: "Here's the thing: this planet's not a place that kids will inherit at some point, far off in the distant future. We live here right now, and we share this planet already."
Bio Info: In February 2011, Milo Cress (then 9 years old) founded the Be Straw Free campaign. He worked together with members of the drinking straw industry, restaurants and other businesses, schools, environmental groups, and concerned citizens to reduce the use and waste of disposable plastic straws.

Quotes: "Cities have to become something like ecosystems."
Bio Info: Polish geologist Jan Zalasiewicz is one author of a report summarizing evidence of the Anthropocene, a term denoting the current geological age where human activity has been a significant influence on climate and the environment. The evidence used includes lake sediment core data and artificial chemicals found in recent stratigraphy.

Quotes: "I believe that the very act of design is about creating places that enable people to be and feel acknowledged, to connect to one another, to heal and to thrive."
Bio Info: An African-American designer, urbanist, and social innovator, Liz Ogbu is an expert in using sustainable design methods in challenging urban environments. She is founder and principal of Studio O, a multidisciplinary innovation practice that works within communities in need to use the power of design to catalyze sustained social impact.
